lesson.title: Going to College
lesson.description: This lesson introduces key steps in planning for college. You'll explore different types of higher education, learn how to apply to college, and discover ways to pay for it. You'll also review important terms and concepts to help you feel more confident as you prepare for college and independent living.
objectives: Know the different types of higher education and degree types;
Identify multiple strategies for financing college;
Understand basic vocabulary and terms around college and independent living.

activities.title: Intro: Are You Planning on Going to College?

questions.question_text: Are you planning on going to college?

options.feedback: That's great that you already know you want to go to college! There's lot to learn about going to college. This lesson should give you the basics.
College is a big decision! This lesson will teach you what you need to know if you decide to go and may even help you make some decisions.

College definitely is not for everybody! This lesson will still provide you with some basic knowledge to make college less daunting if you change your mind. This lesson can also give you knowledge to share with friends and family and help you prepare for other aspects of adulthood.

activities.title: Types of College
activities.instructions: Click a category to see its definition and logos. Then click a logo to read the description.
activities.content: There are many types of colleges and ways to receive <def def='Education or training that takes place after high school, like college, trade school, or apprenticeships.'>post-secondary</def> education. There are also different types of degrees that you can get, providing various levels of <def def='Special skills or knowledge in a subject.'>expertise</def>. Sometimes you won't know what a college offers until you ask, so it's all a matter of finding the perfect fit for you!

examples.title: Trade/Technical Schools
examples.description: Trade and technical schools, sometimes called vocational training schools, are schools that provide education for a specific focus area without requiring general education classes. These schools typically provide certificates or associates degrees, take 1-3 years to complete, and often incorporate lots of hands-on experience.

examples.name: Paul Mitchell
examples.description: A beauty school with multiple locations nationwide. Focus areas include cosmetology, barbering, esthetics, nails, and makeup.

examples.name: EVIT (East Valley Institute of Technology)
examples.description: Located in Arizona; offers career training programs in health services (Examples: nursing and massage therapy), industrial trades (Examples: plumbing and welding), and service industries (aesthetics and cosmetology).

examples.name: Avalon Institute
examples.description: A beauty school focused on esthetics with locations in Arizona, Nevada, Utah and Colorado.

examples.name: NCTA (Nebraska College of Technical Agriculture)
examples.description: Located in Nebraska; offers career training in a variety of agriculture and veterinary technology programs.

examples.name: Margaret H Rollins School of Nursing at Beebe Healthcare
examples.description: A nursing school located in Delaware and incorporated with Beebe Healthcare to provide clinical experiences.

examples.name: CAMTECH School of Construction
examples.description: Located in Florida; offers career-specific training in construction to prepare students to be contractors.

examples.title: Community College
examples.description: Community colleges provide education for a variety of subjects, including general education and more career-specific classes. Most community colleges offer 2-year associates degrees and certificates. Some community colleges have begun offering 4-year bachelor's degrees as well. Community colleges typically have lower <def def='Money paid for school or training'>tuition</def> than 4-year colleges and universities and may be more flexible in the times of day in which classes are offered.

examples.name: Johnson County Community College
examples.description: A community college in Kansas offering 45 different program areas.

examples.name: College of Southern Idaho
examples.description: Home of the Eagles, a community college located in Idaho with more than 60 program areas.

examples.name: Walla Walla Community College
examples.description: A community college located in Washington state that offers primarily associate's degrees through two different campus locations and online.

examples.name: Santa Monica College
examples.description: Located in California; this college is close to the beach and has more than 50 subject areas.

examples.name: Lake Michigan College
examples.description: Home of the Red Hawks, a community college with more than 50 associate degree programs located in Michigan across several campuses.

examples.title: 4-year College
examples.description: 4-year colleges focus on offering bachelor's degrees and provide classes in both general studies and specific focus areas, referred to as <def def='The main subject a student studies in college.'>majors</def>. 4-year can include universities and liberal arts colleges, and are usually private (funded by <def def='Money paid for school or training'>tuition</def> and other sources, sometimes more expensive or exclusive).

examples.name: Lewis & Clark College
examples.description: A private 4-year liberal arts college located in Oregon, offering around 30 different majors to about 2,000 undergraduate students. Lewis & Clark offers intercollegiate sports and programs that allow students to learn outside the classroom.

examples.name: Amherst College
examples.description: A private 4-year liberal arts college located in Massachusetts, has around 2,000 students with about 50% being students of color. Amherst offers about 40 different majors in arts, sciences, social sciences, and humanities.

examples.name: Brigham Young University of Idaho
examples.description: A larger private 4-year college located in Idaho with about 20,000 students and more than 100 different majors. BYU-Idaho is a religious university open to students of all backgrounds.

examples.name: Rhodes College
examples.description: A private 4-year college located in Tennessee offering more than 70 majors, minors, and interdisciplinary programs. Rhodes has strong extracurricular offerings for students including intercollegiate sports and Greek life.

examples.name: Knox College
examples.description: A private 4-year liberal arts college in Illinois with more than 60 majors and around 1,000 students. Knox emphasizes hands-on learning experience through internships and involvement in research.

examples.name: Truman State University
examples.description: A public 4-year college with about 3,500 students located in Missouri. Truman State offers 55 undergraduate programs and competitive athletics.

examples.title: University
examples.description: Universities are larger schools and offer a wide variety of majors and degrees, including certificates, associate's, bachelor's, master's, and doctoral degrees. They may also include professional training such as medical and law schools. Universities can be public (funded by the government, typically cheaper) or private (funded by <def def='Money paid for school or training'>tuition</def> and other sources, sometimes more expensive or exclusive).

examples.name: Arizona State University (ASU)
examples.description: A public university in Arizona with high research activity. ASU is one of the largest public universities and has more than 60,000 undergraduate students.

examples.name: University of South Carolina (USC)
examples.description: A public university in South Carolina with about 45,000 undergraduate students and more than 100 majors. USC is considered a university with high research activity.

examples.name: Florida State University (FSU)
examples.description: A high research public university in Florida with about 30,000 undergraduate students. Florida State is well known for competitive athletics, especially football and baseball.

examples.name: Ohio State University (OSU)
examples.description: A public university in Ohio with high research activity and highly competitive athletic teams. OSU is one of the largest universities by enrollment and has around 50,000 undergraduate students.

examples.name: University of California-Los Angeles (UCLA)
examples.description: A public university in California with high research activity. UCLA has more than 140 majors and has around 30,000 undergraduate students enrolled.

activities.title: Checking Your Understanding: Types of Colleges
activities.content: Did some of those schools look familiar? Hopefully you were able to recognize some or think of other colleges that might fit into those categories. You should now understand some of the differences between types of colleges.
activities.instructions: Let's check and make sure things are making sense so far. There may be more than one correct answer to the questions since there can be more than one pathway to a career.

questions.question_text: Which type of college might you choose to attend to become a doctor?

feedback_config.correct: If you want to become a doctor, you will need to first obtain a bachelor's degree and possibly some additional graduate school training before attending medical school, offered through a University.

questions.question_text: Which type of college might you choose to attend to become a welder?

feedback_config.correct: If you want to become a welder, you would likely attend a trade school or maybe a community college offering a certificate or associate's degree in welding.

questions.question_text: Which type of college might you choose to attend to become an elementary school teacher?

feedback_config.correct: If you want to become a teacher, you would need to attend a 4-year college or university to obtain a bachelor's degree.

questions.question_text: Which type of college might you choose to attend to become a professor?

feedback_config.correct: Becoming a professor would require a master's degree or higher, which can be obtained through graduate school at a university, although you might attend other types of colleges before this.

questions.question_text: Which type of college might you choose to attend to become a chef?

feedback_config.correct: To become a chef, you might attend a trade school specializing in culinary arts, a community college or a 4-year college to receive an associate's or bachelor's degree in culinary arts.

activities.title: Identifying Education Levels in Job Listings
activities.instructions: Look at each job listing below and click where you see the required minimum education level and the preferred education level. Once you've identified both, you'll receive feedback. You can try all three job listings for extra practice.
activities.content:
Choosing what type of college to attend depends on a lot of factors such as location, cost, the type of experience you are seeking, and importantly, the type of job you want to have. Different jobs require different levels of experience.

For this activity, look at a job listing and see if you can find (1) the required minimum education level and (2) the preferred education level. You will need to click on the job listing in those two places to continue. If you want a challenge, you can try out each job listing.

Nice work identifying both the minimum and preferred education levels! These are important areas of job listings to pay attention to which can help you determine whether or not to apply for that job.

activities.title: Finances and College
activities.content:
***Finances and college***  
What you've heard is true--college is expensive. Here we'll go over some of the cost and share strategies for making college affordable. With the right plan and resources, it's possible to avoid debt, or at least keep your costs lower when attending college.

#### **College Costs Include:**

* **Tuition and Fees**: The amount colleges charge for classes, which can vary widely between community colleges, in-state public universities, and private colleges. Other fees may also be incorporated to cover the cost of services like technology and labs.  
* **Room and Board**: Housing, which can cost as much as tuition in some cases. Living off-campus or at home can reduce this.  
* **Meal Plans**: Meal plans allow you to dine on campus. Different colleges will offer different types of meal plans and you can usually opt out if you prefer to cook your own meals to keep costs down.  
* **Books and Supplies**: Textbooks and other materials can add up, but there are ways to save (like renting or buying used).  
* **Health Insurance**: Many colleges require students to have health insurance through the college or privately.  
* **Transportation**: Costs for getting to and from college, whether it's gas, a bus pass, or plane tickets.  
* **Personal Expenses**: Everyday needs like toiletries, laundry, or entertainment.

#### **Factors That Change Costs:**

* **Type of College**: Community colleges tend to be the least expensive, while private universities cost more.  
* **In-State vs. Out-of-State**: Public universities usually charge less for in-state students.  
* **Scholarships and Financial Aid**: These can significantly reduce costs, so students should always apply for aid.  
* **Living Situation**: Living at home, on-campus, or off-campus changes the overall cost.

activities.title: Understanding the FAFSA
activities.instructions: Watch the video to learn more about the FAFSA.
activities.content: The FASFA, or Free Application for Federal Student Aid, is a form available online that identifies financial aid sources you are eligible for with colleges you consider attending. Watch the video to learn more about the FAFSA.
activities._comment: Try out the college cost calculator to better understand how different options can impact the cost of college. Pay attention to whether you are looking at the costs by semester, academic year, or for a full 4-year degree. [College cost calculator] Create a college cost calculator that allows users to estimate their total education costs by selecting options across multiple categories. These categories include tuition and fees (in-state vs. out-of-state, public vs. private universities), room and board (on-campus dorms, off-campus housing, or living at home), meal plans (self-cooking, campus meal plans, or a mix of both), books and supplies (new, used, or rented materials), health insurance (private vs. university-provided), transportation (daily commutes and breaks—car, bus, rideshare, or plane), and personal expenses (toiletries, laundry, entertainment). The calculator should include sliders or dynamic inputs for customizable cost ranges, with hover-based tooltips providing guidance for typical expenses (e.g., $5,000–$15,000 for in-state tuition). Users can toggle between viewing costs per semester, per academic year, or for a 4-year degree, and totals should adjust dynamically based on these options. The design should prioritize a clear layout, grouping each expense category for easy navigation, and offer an intuitive, visually engaging interface for users.

activities.title: Understanding Grants
activities.content:
One type of financial support the FAFSA can offer you is <def def='Free money given to a student for school that does not have to be paid back.'>grants</def>. Grants are financial support that does not typically have to be repaid. These funds will be either given to you directly or applied to your school financial account. When either happens, the grant should be applied first to your tuition and other academic fees, and secondly to your housing. Additional money can go toward other school fees and costs such as textbooks and health insurance.

![Piggy bank](piggy bank.jpg)

activities.title: Understanding Loans
activities.content:
FAFSA can also offer you <def def='Money borrowed for school that must be paid back, usually with extra money called interest.'>loans</def>, which you will be required to pay back after your degree. Depending on the type of loan, these may begin collecting <def def='Extra money paid when borrowing money or earned when saving money.'>interest</def> during or after your degree. If you take a loan and don't finish your degree, you still have to pay for the money you have borrowed! Loans are applied like grants to tuition and fees, then housing and other costs.

![Loan application](loan application.jpg)

activities.title: Understanding Work-Study
activities.content:
<def def='A program where students work part-time jobs to help pay for college.'>Work-study</def> is a form of financial aid that allows you to earn money by working part-time while attending school. The jobs are often on-campus or related to your field of study, making it easier to balance work and academics. Work-study earnings can help cover expenses like books, transportation, and personal costs. This aid is need-based and awarded through FAFSA, so if you're interested, make sure to indicate your preference for work-study when completing your application.

![Work study](work study.jpg)

activities.title: Western Undergraduate Exchange (WUE)
activities.content: The Western Undergraduate Exchange (WUE) is a program offered by the Western Interstate Commission for Higher Education (WICHE) that helps students save on tuition costs by allowing them to pay reduced out-of-state tuition at participating schools. Through WUE, students pay no more than 150% of in-state tuition, which can significantly lower the cost of attending college outside their home state. The program includes students from the following 16 western states and territories: Alaska, Arizona, California, Colorado, Hawaii, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, North Dakota, Oregon, South Dakota, Utah, Washington, Wyoming, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. To take advantage of WUE, check your eligibility and apply early as some schools have limited spots for WUE students or require separate applications.

activities.title: Understanding Scholarships
activities.content: <def def='Free money given for school, usually for good grades, sports, or other achievements.'>Scholarships</def> are another form of financial support that can help you pay for your education. Unlike loans, scholarships do not need to be repaid. They are often awarded based on academic achievements, extracurricular activities, or financial need, and some are specifically for students in certain fields or with unique qualifications. Scholarships do not come from the FAFSA but may come from your school, private organizations, or community groups and can be applied to tuition, housing, or other academic expenses. There are many ways to find scholarships online and your college may have a specific page for available scholarships. Some scholarships may require you to submit a resume, an essay, or other work to be considered.

activities.title: College Majors
activities.content:
A major is the subject someone chooses to study in-depth while attending college, and it ultimately determines the type of career someone will be qualified to have. Majors also determine which classes are required in college to complete a degree.

![Chemistry class](chemistry class.jpg)

activities.title: Exploring Interests
activities.content:
**Take introductory classes in several subjects that you think you might be interested in.** Introductory classes are a great way to try out different classes and can help you get to know faculty and students.

![Professor](professor.jpg)

activities.title: Talking to Departments
activities.content:
**Talk to faculty and students from departments you are interested in.** Sometimes departments hold workshops and socials you can attend, and interacting with other students and faculty can help you figure out if the department is the right fit for you.

![Dance department](dancedepartment.jpg)

activities.title: Career Opportunities
activities.content:
**Learn about careers that are available with a major.** Different majors lead to different career opportunities. If you have a specific career in mind, you'll want a major that works toward that career. If that career falls through, are you open to the other career opportunities?

![Business](business.jpg)

activities.title: Job Availability
activities.content:
**Consider the availability of careers with a given major.** Are there lots of jobs available or will you have to compete for the job you want? Is the field growing or becoming more limited? For example, while poetry might be a hobby with lots to learn, the jobs related to poetry are often very limited.

![Trouble finding a job](trouble finding a job.jpg)

activities.title: Academic Strengths
activities.content:
Classes in a particular subject can get harder as you progress in your degree. **You will want to consider what academic strengths you have and see if you can align your major with those strengths.**

![Academic strengths](academic strengths.jpg)

activities.title: Program Requirements
activities.content:
Different majors and programs may have different requirements for completing your degree, such as completing an internship or thesis. **Learn about these requirements before committing to a major and determine if they are right for you.**

![Graduation](graduation.jpg)

activities.title: Level of Education
activities.content:
**To get the career you want, what level of education will you need?** Some careers may require a higher level of education. Before committing to a major, it's wise to have a good idea of all that it might require.

![Graduating looking up](graduating looking up.jpg)

activities.title: Choosing a Major: Case Study
activities.instructions: In this activity, you'll go through a case study story of a new college student who is choosing a major and determining if it it right for them.As you do, think about your own interests and academic strengths and what you might do in this situation.

activities.title: Exploring Majors
activities.content:
What kind of major would you be interested in? This activity will help you explore different majors and think about the path you might like to take. If you already know what kind of major you are interested in, this activity will help you understand what some of the basic requirements might be.

As you explore majors, keep in mind that the catalog of majors you will be looking at is from *one community college.* Other colleges and universities will have different options for majors as well as different requirements. This activity will familiarize you with the process of looking at majors.

To begin, answer a few questions that will help you narrow down which majors to look at.

![Majors](major.jpg)

On the next page, you should think about the suggestions you were given here. However, you may find that other categories and majors draw your attention too! Feel free to read and explore as many majors as you would like.

activities.title: Applying for College
activities.instructions: Watch this video to learn the basics of what you need to know about applying for college.
activities.content: Applying for college is an exciting step toward your future, but it can feel overwhelming if you're not sure where to start. Don't worry--we've got you covered! In this section, we'll walk you through the key steps of the application process, help you gather everything you'll need, and share strategies for overcoming challenges along the way.

activities.title: College Application Requirements: Overview
activities.content: College applications can take quite a bit of time to complete and you may be surprised by everything they ask for you to submit. Being prepared with documents ahead of time and creating checklists of what each school needs can help you stay organized. Click through the pages to learn about some of the things an application may require.

activities.title: College Application Requirements: Application Fees
activities.content:
Many colleges charge an application fee, which can range from $20 to $100. If the fee is a problem, you can request a fee waiver. For students not currently in school, you can ask the college admissions office directly or check their website for a fee waiver form--many schools have options for students facing financial hardship.

![Fee waiver](feewaiver.jpg)

activities.title: College Application Requirements:Transcripts
activities.content:
A transcript is a record of your high school classes and grades. If you've changed schools or are not currently enrolled, contact your most recent school district to request a copy. If you're unsure where to start, a case manager or teacher may be able to help you locate the correct school or district office.

![Transcripts](transcripts.png)

activities.title: College Application Requirements: High School Diploma or GED
activities.content:
Most colleges need proof that you've graduated high school or earned a GED. If you're still working on earning your diploma or GED, focus on completing it, as this is usually the first step for applying to college. If you already earned it but lost the paperwork, you can contact the school or testing center where you graduated or took your GED to request a copy.

![High school graduation](highschool graduation.png)

activities.title: College Application Requirements: Standardized Test Scores
activities.content:
Some colleges require scores from tests like the SAT or ACT, but many schools are now test-optional. If you've taken one of these tests before but don't have your scores, you can request them from the test organization (College Board for SAT or ACT.org). If you haven't taken these tests, look for test-optional schools or ask your facility staff if testing is available.

![Standardized tests](standardizedtests.png)

activities.title: College Application Requirements: Resume
activities.content:
College applications may ask for a resume which shows your activities, jobs, volunteer work, and accomplishments. Even if you don't have a long list of activities, focus on what you have done--like learning skills, working in groups, or setting goals.

![First job cashier](firstjobcashier.png)

activities.title: College Application Requirements: IEP or 504 Documentation
activities.content:
If you used an IEP or 504 Plan in high school, these documents can help you get support in college. If you don't have the paperwork, ask someone at your facility, a past school district, or your caseworker for help. Colleges have disability services offices to guide you through requesting accommodations.

![IEP or 504 Documentation](IEP504.png)

activities.title: College Application Requirements: FAFSA
activities.content:
The FAFSA helps you access financial aid like grants, loans, or work-study. Even if you don't think you'll qualify, it's worth completing--it's free and can open up opportunities for funding. The FAFSA is covered in this lesson when we talk about finances and college.

![Eating cereal](eating cereal.png)

activities.title: College Application Requirements: Placement Testing
activities.content:
Some colleges may ask you to take placement tests to decide the best level for your classes. If you don't know your skill level in math or English, don't worry--these tests help you start where you're most comfortable. Placement testing can sometimes be arranged online or through your college after you've been accepted.

![International student](internationalstudent.jpg)

activities.title: College Application Requirements: Essays or Personal Statements
activities.content:
Many colleges ask for a short essay or personal statement to learn more about you. If you're not sure what to write about, think about challenges you've overcome, your goals, or a moment that shaped you. Keep it honest and focus on your story--there's no wrong answer. And don't forget to proofread!

![Essay](essay.jpg)

activities.title: College Application Requirements: References
activities.content:
References are people who can write letters or talk about your strengths. If you don't have teachers or counselors to ask, think about other adults who know you well--like a caseworker, volunteer supervisor, or mentor. Be sure to ask early and explain what the college is looking for.

![References](references.jpg)

activities.title: College Application Requirements: Double-Check Requirements
activities.content:
Each college is different, so check their website to make sure you've included everything they need. Some may ask for extra materials, like portfolios or interviews. Stay organized by making a list for each school.

![Checklist](checklist.jpg)

activities.title: Going to College Reflection
activities.instructions: Use this space to write anything you'd like -- things to remember, what you learned from this lesson, questions you still have, or something else.
activities.content:
You've just finished this lesson on Going to College. Take a moment to think about the most important things you want to remember. These lessons aren't just for now -- they're tools you can carry with you into the future.

![College photo](collegepic.jpg)
